LS(1) General Commands Manual LS(1)

NAME

ls — list directory contents

SYNOPSIS

ls [-1AadhklR] [file ...]

DESCRIPTION

For each operand that names a file of a type other than directory, ls displays its name as well as any requested, associated information. For each operand that names a file of type directory, ls displays the names of files contained within that directory, as well as any requested, associated information.

If no operands are given, the contents of the current directory are displayed.

The options are as follows:

-1
(The numeric digit one.) Force output to be one entry per line.
-A
Include directory entries whose names begin with a dot (‘.’) except for . and ...
-a
Include directory entries whose names begin with a dot (‘.’).
-d
Directories are listed as plain files (not searched recursively).
-h
When used with the -l option, use unit suffixes: Byte, Kilobyte, Megabyte, Gigabyte, Terabyte and Petabyte in order to reduce the number of digits to three or less using base 2 for sizes.
-k
Display file sizes in kilobytes when used with the -l option.
-l
(The lowercase letter ell.) List in long format.
-R
Recursively list subdirectories encountered.

EXIT STATUS

The ls utility exits 0 on success, and >0 if an error occurs.

EXAMPLES

List all files in the current directory in long format:

$ ls -la

List files with human-readable sizes:

$ ls -lh

List only the names of subdirectories:

$ ls -d */

SEE ALSO

chmod(1), find(1), stat(1), symlink(7)

STANDARDS

The ls utility is compliant with the IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (“POSIX.1”) specification.

AUTHORS

vibeutils implementation by Travis Cole

August 2, 2025 macOS 15.6
